description.text: A very simple STL that is actually a simplification of the STEP-file by Marco Alici (http://marcoalici.wordpress.com/2012/01/28/me-and-the-raspberrypi/#) I simplified it so RepRaps/Skeinforge etc don't choke on it. Please don't use this as a reference to make cases. I didn't double check the geometry. Don't come crying if your injection moulding-mould doesn't fit the Pi we're all waiting for.

Print for reference. Think of the printed model as a teleported version of your preordered Pi. Profit.
Prints nicely on an Ultimaker (some overhanging parts)

description.text:
I have been working in this design for weeks, trying to improve his printability, and making it as simple and smooth as possible.

The ORIGINAL IDEA was to create an affordable modular lamp, providing the chance to build real-size lamps with a domestic FDM 3D printer (21 x 20 cm maximum printing size). The only parts that are not printable are the electrical stuff: wires, led strips, etc.

TECHNICAL REQUIREMENTS:

Additional technical requirements taken into account are described below, in descending order of significance:

· Simple design, reducing as high as possible the number of required parts. The ideal would be an unique part which would be repeated and assemble in the correct position.

· Simple geometry, in order to be printed without support. It would be perfect if the parts are unibody, without additional pieces, covers or gears.

· Fully printable

· It should be highly modular, allowing the assembly of 3 or more "floors".

· Low-cost

· Nice looking appearance.

ABOUT THIS VERSION: This is a definitive version, with lot of improvements since the first prototype release. Each ring adds a height of aproximately 12cm, and theorically you can assembly as many as you want until the ceiling doesn't let you continue (~2.5meters). If you set a new height record, please share your achievement with us!!

You can see below a brief description of the main improvements:

UPDATE v.22

· Joints between rings have been redesigned. Now they are stronger, and have been checked to fit perfectly. I have printed them several times because of the tight tolerance, but now they are able to fix the angle to the intended one with no error.

UPDATE v1.0

· Supports redesigned. Now they are really easy to remove!

· New diffuser design. With a 0,4mm width they are absolutely flexible even if they are printed in PLA.

· New cover for the TOP ring.

· Added a hole in the base for the IR sensor.

· Base holes are all normalised. You can see the addittional components table for further information.

FUTURE DEVELOPMENT:

I am also working in an automated version, with one degree of freedom. I won't tell you anything else so you can imagine :P

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

For smooth finish I recommend to use 0.1 resolution for rings. For the base support it might be enough with 0.2.

Mounting instructions

While you are printing the base support, you will need to pause the printing and fit the connectors in their correct position. Then you can continue printing.

With this design you can get a solid base support with no covers!

For additional information take a look to the pdf.

I've been on a quest to improve the print quality of my MendelMax 2.0. My gold standard is the output of the Replicator 2, and I'm getting closer and closer. These parts are my latest improvements and definitely make a difference. I've been using Ohmeye's Z Isolators (shown in yellow in the photo) from here: https://www.dropbox.com/sh/3uyotd400xp2ef5/2pLnjCypcV/STLs/Z%20Isolators/ohmeye_mm2_isolator_release%202x.STL And I've also been using my stiff Z couplers: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:173335 Together I've been getting mostly good print quality. But sometimes I ran into problems. Ohmeye's Z isolator has a single bump that sits under a screw hole on the metal bracket on the MM2. It turns out the isolator can catch on that hole, reducing the print quality. This part (light blue above the yellow isolator) provides a smooth surface for the Z isolator, completely covering the holes in the bracket.

Print two of these parts, one for each side. Each part has three posts that fit into the existing screw holes to hold them in place. Insert them into the bracket so they're between the bracket and the Z isolator.

comments.text: Hi john, I was wondering if you ever solved your z artifacts problem and found the root cause? I never really noticed how bad mine is until I built a delta printer and saw how perfect z layering could be. So far I added the ohm-eye z-isolators along with these covers. I also printed your lead screw constraint, but I have problems with them since my lead screws done align perfectly in the middle of the circle. I have tried a to adjust things to get them centered with no avail. I am still yet to try solid couplers. One thing I noticed about my printer is that the build platform is not stable solid, there seems to be a lot of play in the bearings, even if I squeeze them and re-tighten them. I was wondering if you had the same problem and could provide any other tips?

title: Robotic hand  servo powered
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to know more about servo and servo control.
So i redesigned my hand, to fit servos.
I used the mg90 servo and a pololu servo controller (micro maestro 6 servo usb controller) to control these 5 servos.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CrL5BxtCJHs&feature=youtu.be

Print all the finger parts 5x (except finger dip parts)
Servo rods 3x (gives you one spare)
Thumb adaptor 1x
Baseplate 1x
Cover 1x
Lower arm cover 1x

The finger dip:
There are 2 versions. Smooth and with grip. Choose the version you like. The gripped ones are the finger-dip-parts-all-parts.
The smooth one are diverend size. Dig 1 and 5 are same size. Dig 2 and 4 also. And dig 3 is the largest of them all.

----------UPDATE-------
The Sketchup file is uploaded now.

------------UPDATE 2--------
Added the wrist adaptor, this one is compatible with the lower arm from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2727176
The finger parts from that design are compatible with this one. Less parts and easier to assemble.

Printer Brand:

Deltaprintr

Printer:

Deltaprintr Kit

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The lower arm cover is a solid. So print this with no infill, top and bottom. Use the amount of perimeters you prefer.
If you have already printed my other hand project http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1830958. You only have to print a few new parts . The finger-mcp-part is different. The servo-base-plate and the thumb-adaptor.

I included some exploded views to explain assembly of the digits and servo placement.

I used a 2020 rod to mount the hand on. And the cover is mounted to the 2020.

The servo rods are printed straight, and have to be thermoformed using a heat gun.
This is the easiest way to make them fit.
First twist them 90 dgr (lenght), place them onto the servo and finger. Some times this gives some stress on the servo or finger mounting. Just heat the rod, just a little. Then give it the final curve. Don't over tighten the screws to fasten these rods. The need to be loose so they can act as an pivot point.

All the fingers have the same mockup. Except the thumb has an adaptor to give it a angle to the base plate. Front servos are mounted under the baseplate. And are 180 dgr turned compared to rear servos. The rear servos are mounted on top of the baseplate

description.text:
Edit 1: I added a Thumb cap. I like it better without, but whoever needs it can use it.

I wanted to have a fidget spinner, but I didn't want to put in three or more bearings. So I designed a spinner which uses M8 nuts as weights, and it works great! It is also a bit smaller than the ones with bearings, making it easier to spin with small hands.

It is designed to have a tight fit, but if needed the parts can be taken out after putting them in.

With cleaned bearings, it spun up to one minute and with uncleaned ones it gets up to 15 seconds of spinning.

description.text:
This is a replacement x-carriage for when you want to use the E3D V6 x-carriage for Anet a6 to improve print quality and speed. it can be used without any modifications to the printer i.e X end stop and Cooler fan can be used from the original carriage.
The carriage itself is printed with the fan brackets on the bed and the E3D mount groove opening on top. locking jig is printed with E3D mount upwards.

A version with a inductive sensor attachment and one with direct drive has been uploaded!

description.text:
This is a 3d printed Snapchat Logo code. It does scan. For scanablity high contrast is necessary. In one color it can be used for decorative purpose only.

These codes have been produced by CustomGhostCodes.com.

Print in Black filament and switch to yellow filament after the 1mm layer has finished. This will produce a scanable code.

Getting your own code:
If you want to use your own code, there are a few steps to achieve this.

  1. Download your Snapcode SVG from Snapchat
  2. Go into your favorite design program and pull the SVG into a model.
  3. Export to a .STL file
  4. Slice with your printer settings.
  5. Add pause code to switch filiment color.

Those are all the steps and you can produce your own code.

If you want this process done for you check out www.CustomGhostCodes.com
They will create your STL or complete the entire process for you.

author: sbeardsley

description.text: A simple case for a PS Vita with hinged lid and opened letters.  I welcome any comments!  Enjoy.

I made this one pictured out of glow in the dark filament so I could easily see the case at night.  It's a nice fit, especially if you add some mole skin, fabric, or a couple strips of weatherstripping or something inside to prevent rattling.  I also used standard paperclips bent and cut as wires for the hinges.  I designed this to not need rafts or supports and it sliced with slic3r and printed perfectly on my 8" i3 Prusa.  The only minor problem I had was lifting on the base sides in a couple places.  However, I used some thick ABS Acetone mixture painted inside the lifted spots and clamped it down overnight and lifting was fixed.  Also, on my ABS, the lid's clasp piece was a little too fragile and broke on me once, but I made it slightly wider for this uploaded version so hopefully it works better, but of course ABS isn't as elastic as some other plastics.

UPDATE: I have abandoned this project for the time being. With the advent of the Pocket
CHIP, I no longer have a purpose for my Pocket PC. I may pick it up again later.

After a long hiatus from 3D printing (6 months); last week I decided to get my printer back together. After a Radds + Arduino Due and a MS all metal hot end upgrades; I got back to work on an incomplete project. My version of the Raspberry Pi Pocket PC.

(Previous Version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1739092 )

The new version has much the same hardware, the basic differences are, a better battery (4000 mAh), thinner design, slightly longer and wider, but ~14 mm thinner.

This is only preliminary, there are still a few things I need to change; thinner shorter HDMI cable, incorporate a slide switch to disconnect the Pi from the DC-DC converter, and move some holes around, that's about it

author: Emrys1

title: Omnistand External Direct Spool Mount Mix

description.text:
When I mount spools outside, I prefer mounting the spool parallel to the frame. So I did this mashup to use with the external OmniStand mount I made (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2171557). The side effect is the double spool mount cannot hold 2 spools anymore (I just print one more, which I need anyway).

IMPORTANT !!
Like my other OmniStand Mix, I did the mashup in FlashPrint, so you must rename the "stl" file extension to "fpp" because thingiverse don't support fpp uploads. I have no intention to do a STL for now as the mash prints nicely straight from FlashPrint and is designed specifically for the Flashforge Dreamer only. I also want to demonstrate how easy it is to do quick customising in slicers using just the scale/move/cut functions.
The mix is on the left, with the spool rod directly connected without using the spool stand. The original method is to the right (black spool rod with spool stand).

comments.text: Do not adjust the position of the 3 objects, I have measured and aligned them to print as a single piece. If your printer is well calibrated, you do not need supports inside the hole for the spool rod to lock in. But I also tried printing with the auto support and it is also very easy to remove the supports.

title: Hypercube 3D Printer - Adjustable/Extended Fan Duct (For clone/different hotends)

description.text:
I built Tech2C's Hypercube, but the fan duct is too short for my e3D v6 Clone. Its blowing directly onto the heater block. If you decide to make one, please upload a make. I would love to see how yours turn out

With this, the fan duct can be adjusted 2mm up or down by sliding the screw in the slot.

At it's highest, it's the same as the default duct. At it's lowest, it's approximately 2mm below the default. I have mine adjusted to ~1.5mm below default.

I also removed 2mm from the top of the duct, so it doesnt bottom out on the fan itslef, preventing movement.

Note it may require a little filing. You do not want the screw's threads to engage in the slot. I personally have mine somewhere in the middle of the range.

1.) Opened Tech2C's fan duct in NetFabb Basic. I cut it directly through the screw holes. I moved one half 2mm away from the other. I removed the wall Netfabb generated (since it needs to be open, for air to apss through.) I exported each.
2.) Luckily and to my surprise, when importing into Meshmixer, they stayed 2mm apart. I expected to have to resituate them. I then made both solid, selected the face of one, and extruded it 2mm. I could in theory extrude this more to make it even more adjustable, but at that point it would be below the nozzle in most cases.
3.) I made it solid again in Meshmixer, combined the parts, made it solid again, repaired it in netfabb, then finally on my third "make solid" in Meshmixer, repetier decided it was printable.

remixed_from.author: AzzA
remixed_from.title: Z braces for Wanhao Duplicator i3, Cocoon Create, Maker Select, and Malyan M150 i3 3D printers.

title: Wanhao i3 Plus Z Brace w/level (feet only)

description.text:
This is a remix of both abrandi's mod of 3dspool_canada's feet and TEN1964's mod for the i3 PLUS to be used with Azza's popular zBraces.

This version takes abrandi's mod in that it allows to use two nuts on each foot in order to stabilize the gantry in both directions and then adds TEN1964's mod to provide full base leveling capability.

I also used Azza's "Z braces for Wanhao Duplicator i3:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:921948

In addition to my versions, just print the top_right, top_left and 4 of the MK2 balls from Azza's braces.

Use these with Anti-vibration feet for Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus from shusy: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2130829

Or purchase Threaded Furniture Glides (SKU 193 637) 1/4" thread with a press fit threaded plug from Home Depot or your local home supply store.
(For my setup, shusy's side feet for under the gantry tower were not tall enough, you may or may not need to change the height of those based on how much you need to level the base).

See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2021974 for more details on the leveling.

Note that the way the leveling feet positions are away from the printer frame, it puts additional pressure on the mounting screws, more so on the front bracket parts. Do not skimp on the infill, go with 70% or more. If you don't use a high infill and you try to tighten the M5 screws to where they should be, the infill can give way and the part will crack at the layer central to the screw mounting hole. I learned the hard way and had to reprint the feet.

Another way to help relieve the stress would be that once you have the base leveled with the furniture guides or printed feet, that you create for blocks that match the height of the lift that the feet give to the printer and place (glue) them under the base of each corner directly below the screw position to help support the weight.

title: Ducati tail light and license plate mount

description.text:
Don't tell anyone... but I bought a Ducati [sexy] that had a salvage title [ugh!] and I have no idea what happened to this poor thing but the previous owner hack-sawed the safety rail in the back and mounted everything back there with metal scraps. Quite ugly.

SO, I took it upon myself to not only make a pair of plugs to cover the unsightly exposed hacksawed bar ends, but also the other pieces that mount the lights just under the seat and the license plate in a visible spot under the rear safety bar. Sad how it's not there anymore... Anyways, I think it works out pretty well.

Let's hope you don't have to resort to this... but if you do, it's all yours for the taking. :)

If you found this useful, please share your work and be sure to peruse my other submissions which are almost as varied as they are many:

http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs

Enjoy!

description.text:
This is a "Nintendo Switch" case for a Raspberry Pi 7" Touchscreen display.

It's slightly bigger than the original game console (117%).

Instructions

title: Anet A8 - RepRapDiscount Full Graphic LCD Holder

description.text:
Yet another holder for the RepRapDiscount Full Graphic LCD (http://www.gearbest.com/lcd-led-display-module/pp_228315.html)
The spacer should be printed 4 times for the LCD-Sandwich PCB.
There is a hole in the front panel for the contrast potentiometer.
The Display holder uses the original LCD holes in the Anet A8 frame.
You should add a 470-560 Ohm resistor between Pin2 and Pin3 (of the LCD) to improve the contrast range.

To use the Display on the Anet A8 printer you have to make a simple adapter and change some firmware settings in the Skynet3D firmware "pins_ANET_10.h" : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2103748

Attention: Print height is reduced to approx 19cm!
If you don't want to lose build height just use the bottom holes and screw them in the top holes of the frame.

title: Rubber Band Gun, 6-shot, semi-automatic, laser-cut
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Have a laser cutter?  You can churn out Lyratron XRBGs (Experimental Rubber Band Guns) all day!  We developed these pistols as Xmas presents for our bros, and as usual we decided to open source the design.  It's a simple 6-shot step-up mechanism.  We used 1/8" acrylic glass (plexiglass) and manually rounded the edges of the outer (stationary) band retention notches with a Dremel to improve reliability.  Have fun!

INSTRUCTIONS:
  • Lase SVG onto a single sheet of 1/8" thick plexiglass.
  • Glue pieces together with hot melt glue, making sure to keep glue away from the sliding middle (trigger) piece.
  • Once assembled, carefully round off the edges of the outer (stationary) band retention notches.
  • Spray paint if desired.
  • Lase and install wood grips if desired.

I've printed a few spinners for my family - I've not bothered to design my own since there are plenty of good designs out there (I've been printing lovewaffle's cog triple spinner) but I wasn't happy about most of the designs for the hub caps, which are either hard to fit, or can lead to friction against the bearing, or both, so I designed these:

  • pedestal on the shaft so the only contact with the bearing is with the inner rotating part
    -shafts are very slightly tapered, so go in easily but snug down firmly
  • shaft halves interlock (you can put a tiny blob of glue into the hole and they'll never come out
  • outer caps are wide enough to act as a dust cap to prevent any grit getting into open ball races, yet small enough so they don't protrude beyond the spinner's inner diameter
  • nice height and taper on the outer caps to make them pleasant to hold.
  • inside rim of the outer caps is slightly tapered to minimise any messy printed edges that could rub against the bearing.

So all in all, massively over-designed for what it is. Mine spins for over a minute with a hybrid-ceramic bearing now.

I printed mine 0.1mm with 100% infill, and you probably want to print 2 or 3 sets at once so that you don't get hot-printed blobby err - male parts

This is a 1/8" thick acrylic, laser-cut, top cover that protects the power supply and electronics on my printer. Before I made these covers, I had some scraps drop into the fan of the power supply. So I made these covers to help protect both the power supply, and the electronics from items (such as screws) dropping down and shorting or breaking the fan.

Cut two of these. If you have access to a laser, you'll need a sheet of 1/8" thick acrylic that is about 18" by 11" for the two parts. The left and right sides are mirror images, so you can cut out two identical parts and just turn one over.  
Take care and you can work each cover into place on a fully assembled printer. Then hold in place using three T nuts and M5 x 8 screws. For my cover, I used "smoke" acrylic, which has gray tint that you can see through.

Designed using ThinkerCAD.

This magnetic scissors holder is universal as you can customize it to fit any scissors;

The joined SCAD script has the following parameters:

  • holder height
  • holder wall thickness
  • scissors upper width
  • scissors lower width
  • scissors thickness
  • magnets diameter
  • magnets thickness

Advice on parameters' value: while measuring your scissors,
provide some space to the scissors to let it float in the holder.

Provided STL has the following parameters' values (in millimeters):
holder_height = 40;
holder_wall_thickness = 2;
scissors_upper_width = 24;
scissors_lower_width = 15;
scissors_thickness = 11;
magnets_diameter = 8;
magnets_thickness = 4;

You can glue magnets on the holder using a hot glue gun (it's what I did, it's strong enough).

If the holder is slipping on the surface of a fridge (for instance :) ), you can add some neoprene spray glue on the magnets' surface.
Example of neoprene spray glue: https://www.amazon.fr/Bostik-SA-n%C3%A9opr%C3%A8ne-multi-usage-a%C3%A9rosol/dp/B008F7W4E0

PCB heated bed. I'm working on this idea for nearly two months, inspired by http://www.neufeld.newton.ks.us/electronics/?p=864 .

tested at 110W and its working flawlesly, gives 108Â°C in few mins
Now I'm working on great mounting solution

• 22x20cm hated area
  • you can select what resistance you want 1.3ohms (110W at 12V) or 21ohms
  • you dont need any steel or aluminium on top, just plane kapton tape
    • (I'm testing it at 21ohms setup with 55V PSU which gives me 144W and about 110-120Â°C, will test with 12V soon and I'll give a report)

etch it on FR4 35um copper board, should cost about $20 or if you are interested email me I can probably etch some for you. Not tinning or copper plating, this would lower the resistance.
There are 4 resistors on the board, final resistance depends how you connect them by solder bridges. Parallel -> 1.3ohms. Serial -> 21ohms.

Here are a number of plane curves, epicycloids, made three dimensional by extending them along the z axis as was done for the pentagram in thing:209452 - Star Ornaments from Pentagrams. A hole for hanging allows a mobile to be constructed. Depending on input parameters the epicycloid can have 1 cusp, the cardioid, 2 cusps, the nephroid, 3, 4, 5, 6, etc. cusps, becoming a circle as the number of cusps approaches infinity. Six examples of output from the openSCAD code are included, many more are possible. Stl files are: cardioid_mark_1.stl
nephroid_mark_2.stl
epicycloid_mark_3.stl
epicycloid_mark_4.stl
epicycloid_mark_5.stl
epicycloid_mark_6.stl

The openSCAD code constructs both double sided and single sided versions of the curves.  Single sided versions are given here as the double sided versions are more difficult to  print.  The examples shown in the image above are the result of gluing two single sided prints together.  
The single sided files can be printed directly on the build surface.

Don't know what else to call it. I needed something that showed me that auto bed levelling was moving the z axis, which is difficult to see when your just looking at an 8mm threaded rod, so I designed this clip that you just put on the top of you z axis and you can see the rod turning.

comments.author: PilksUK

description.text: Updated the excellent FixturePlate.scad so I could generate a wall plate for my RGB sliders. Measurements are optimized for Bourns PTA3043-2010CIB503 30mm sliders, update the .scad file for other sizes. Also used Arial Rounded MT for the RGB labels. I printed a draft version (pic attached) to check the measurements, will now test with a slower (4 hour!) version. I'm also going to upload a new scad file with the text bigger, since it didn't come out well in my test. Newer version adds extensions for the screwholes so it will lie flatter. Edited to add some details.

title: 2.4" & 2.8" TFT Desktop stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update 1: There was the wish for the same in 2.8" as the same display is available in this, a bit bigger, size. I added the files. (The bottom cover is the same)

With a small cheap TFT and an Arduino or ESP8266 many useful displays for your desktop can be made. Starting from ordinary clocks or weather stations also ideas like a display for the actual exchange rates, word clock, train schedule or even the time for the journey home can be found in the Internet.

But it's all the same, if your are a "maker" you can't use your inventions in the living room, the office, etc. unless you give it a professional appearance - Who like to display a "home brew" thing?

This very simple stand allows to cover your 2.4 TFT (based on a ILI9341) and a Wemos mini ESP8266 board with an appearance like bought from a gadget dealer - without any "home brew" touch.

The TFT, the ESP8266 and the two covers stick together without any glue or screws. As an example i used the color weather station of Dani Eichhorn - https://blog.squix.org/2016/10/esp8266-weather-station-color-code-published.html (Note I used a slightly different TFT, a TJCTM24024-SPI which has the same electronics but is 2.4" instead of 2.2".)

The entire design is done with Tinkercad

Notes:

printed it in ABS red

I've been on a quest to improve the print quality on my MendelMax 2.0 printer. Watching a Replicator 2, I've noticed the fan makes a huge difference. I had been using two fans angled toward the top, using these mounts: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:139952. You can see the latest version of this mount on the right side of the photo. In an effort to improve the cooling airflow, I created this fan duct, which screws onto the carriage. This fan duct is thicker than many you'll find, but does a much better job. Here's why. The fan supplied by Makers Tool Works for the MendelMax 2.0 is good at moving air, but it can't pressurize the air much. So if the output vents are too small, most of the air flows back out of the fan on the outside of the blades rather than flowing across the part you're trying to cool. Using larger vents allows more air to flow around the part. With this duct I've gotten the best print quality so far with my printer. Bridging works much better, and I get less sag on overhangs. The last photo shows an example of before and after switching to using the fan duct. The light blue part is without the fan duct, while the dark blue part on the right is with this fan duct. You can see how much of a difference it makes. Both of these parts were printed from exactly the same g-code file.

comments.text: Where can I find the actual extrude mount?
comments.author: vserluco

comments.text:
Any chance you can make a Replicator 2 version? The current replicator 2x fans are terrible. I don't know who designed them but they clearly didn't understand material properties, heat dynamics or anything coherent, in science. Its anemic, only cools one side of the print because of the square heat block, which makes drastic differences on the opposite side (rear) especially on inner shells, bridges and overhangs. Its also far too close to the nozzle and melts away slowly above 230, and it's made from ABS which was a horrible idea for their design. It also cools the heater block, especially on slow filaments like Tglase and makes it 8-10c colder than your setting, it causes the PID auto tune in the firmware to go nuts. Great for LaywooD3 temperature wood grain scripts but that's pretty much it. And you can't even print LaywooD3 on a .4MM without major problems. I wasted 2 coils (0.5 pounds worth) testing and I finally got settings to work without problem, and it was a 100% infill print. I have the settings saved in a bundle CFG. If you want them, let me kknow, ill send it.
BTW, Im seeing some fan ducts that have water channels in the shell, with inlet and outlet ports designed for a tiny water pump and rubber hoses. Perhaps we can trade some models or settings sheets as a barter system. I love your design and would love it even more if it would fit my Replicator 2 duel nozzle. Perhaps we can trade some settings sheets ffor the trouble? I spend all day testing and taking notes in the lab and and have 11 years in the engineering and design field. Its my job at the moment to work out different settings for different printers. I'm sure I have what you need!

title: The ball screw fit for the linear guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I spent a long time to decide, should I make a whole new XYZ machine, or upgrade my Delta(cause I dont like delta very much, hard to adjust,not very very accurate=.=). And at last, one of my friend made linear guide version delta with three ball screw pairs~seems good.

Then, I designed this~~a ball screw fit for the linear guide~

I planed to use the 1204 screw, though 4mm maybe too short, but my stepper motors are 1.8degree/step, that's 200steps/round, means 0.02mm/step~and I use the 1/16 subdivision， so that's 0.00125mm/division. If I want move 0.01mm(I think that's enough for a delta machind), it should only move 8 divisions~all the length will be calculated into a whole number of steps.

I have finished the design, then I'll get some new 2020 aluminum bars and upgrade my Delta~hope there'll be no problem

description.text:
This is a redesign of a cell phone stand that I previously posted on Thingverse (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1949424). I didn’t like the way it worked when the phone was plugged into a USB charging cord, so I incorporated a charging pad into the design (“Anker Wireless Charger PowerPort Qi Wireless Charging Pad” from Amazon.com, https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00Y839YMU/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o09_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1).

This part prints best on its side. I put rubber feet on the bottom to keep it from sliding on my desk. I also added a piece of foam tape on the lip that holds the cell phone so that the phone doesn’t slide around. Finally, I secured the charging pad using double-stick foam tape

The photos shown a variation that has my company’s logo on the face, but I eliminated that in the STL file uploaded here. I left the USB cord accessible at the top (instead of burying it inside the part so that I could easily unplug the cord to charge my USB Headset. It doesn’t look as nice this way, but it’s more functional for me.

Enjoy!

This is a remix of the fan mount by krwynn. While his design is very efficient, I didn't like the way it hung outboard to the right. In operation, it would come very close to crashing into my right side x assembly. So I opted to use a 30mm fan mounted topside. I made 2 versions. nema14A is the one i use because i found that my assembly had a perfect fit tolerance so that I could just slip the mount down onto the motor and it fit very snug. Nema14B is for those of you with different tolerances and it should fit onto the motor like krwynn's original mount. Tested with a 4 hour print of Groot and the motor was barely luke warm. I also used the fan grill from the Toranado fan grill contest which can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1750609

UPDATE 4/2/17: added nemaFlush.stl for the new side/flush mount Toranado. It fits snug BUT this is because I use the x-carriage by Toranado: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1302584. I can't confirm how it will fit using a different x-carriage.

Once printed, it can stand on its nose and tail, or upright just on its tail (may require a little bit of support/putty magic). Original 3DS model from: http://www.3dmodelfree.com/models/26530-0.htm
(Has been modified, rigged to curve the dolphin.)

Printed on MakerBot Replicator 2 with ReplicatorG at 0.27mm layer height with raft and full support. Regular version STL is about 9cm long head to tail, takes about an hour to print; "large" version is about 13.5cm, takes a little over 2 hours (same geometry, just scaled).

remixed_from.author: morecat_lab
remixed_from.title: Universal Project Box for Type C PCB

description.text:
Many thanks to morecat_lab for the universal project box. This was my first introduction to OpenSCAD and for that I am grateful! I find OpenSCAD fits my design style much better than other tools I have used. Check it out!

The basic box became my starting point. I sized it to fit the chosen PCB (60mm x 40mm with 56mm and 36mm mount holes), added a 29mm mount point for a speaker (along with a pattern of holes), holes for an audio jack, control buttons, and indicator LED as well as the power switch. The last two holes for access to the USB port and dfplayer SD card were trickier to place because they depend on the position of the parts, but with a bit of fiddling I think it's pretty close now.

The drawing is of the final revision. The photo is my last, complete and fully functional prototype version.

author: andrejc

title: X-UAV Mini Talon Twin Motor Conversion v2

description.text:
This project is a simplified version of my original "X-UAV Mini Talon Twin Motor Conversion" project -

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2024070

It came about as a request from an RCGroup poster asking for somthing he could cut out of plywood so I made three basic shapes and gave them to him in PDF form so he would have a cut template.

I then decided the best way to test the whole twin conversion idea was to use these simpler pieces to create something I could change quickly and easily and zero in on the best set-up. I then added flanges, cut-outs for motor wires and markings so assembly would be easier. Turns out they work really well so I haven't removed them from one of my Mini Talons (yet).

Of course they aren't much to look at but they are very easy to print and you could even print them (one at a time) on a 100 x 100 print bed. Like the updated original version, the key is behind the wing tube so once glued they are very secure.

I would recommend using ABS fillament and ABS pipe cement to glue the pieces together as this is super strong then use E6000 or Beacons FoamTac to glue them to the wing and don't forget the key!

More Mini Talon Parts!
http://www.itsqv.com/QVM/index.php?title=Mini_Talon_Parts_Compilation

A simple dashboard for the Gloomhaven board game. Can be used with or without the Lower section; with the lower section glued under the upper section, the Character mat can be slid inside the dashboard so the picture shows through. Without the lower section, the area where the picture would be can be used to store loot and other tokens. I mean, you could do that even with the lower section in place - up to you.

The large slots on the left and right are for your Discard and Lost cards respectively. The large slot top left is for your remaining deck, the two thin slots below it are for your two cards you're playing this turn. The two slots in the top right are for your item cards; having them on display individually took up too much space, so I figure one slot for body items, one slot for "other" items.

The six squares are for 12mm dice (that's what I have loads of). I use the top for XP, the bottom for HP, as the bottom row is slightly easier to get to. First dice slot is for tens, second and third slots are for two dice to count 0-9 (I let the first go up to five then for six, I'd use five + one - it's up to you). That should let you get up to 69 on both - plenty! I looked at a dial solution, but I couldn't fit one into this design and keep it all on the printbed.

Lastly, the two angled trays are for your attack modifier cards. I start with he whole deck in the upper tray, then as I draw cards, they go in the lower tray.

I've printed this on a Wanhao D4S (the .x3g file is configured to use the left extruder in this case) after running it through Simplify3D.

This my first submission to Thingiverse, feedback is welcome!

A rough sketch on paper first to lay out the various slots, then over to Fusion360 to model it. I'm still learning Fusion360 so it took me a while to figure out how to do the slopes (I used the Draft function in the end), and I used the Taper option in the Push/Pull command to add a slant to the card slots.

First print came out with dimensions just a touch too small - plus my 12mm dice, all from the same source, turned out to have slight differences in size, so I enlarged the die holes.

I am testing a new version with slightly less tapering and also with raised HP and XP text.

Update

"Dash v7 - upper" is a revised version of the upper half of the dashboard.

  • Rear "attack modifier" deck space adjusted to make getting at the last few cards easier
  • supports around the vertical card slots reduced to the stand at an angle
  • XP and HP idents added

The lower section is unchanged.

remixed_from.author: alexan9er
remixed_from.title: Anet A8 Z Endstop Switch Holder

title: Anet A8 Z Endstop Fine Tuner

description.text:
This is an amalgamation of several different mods that I used to create the Z Finely Adjustable Endstop that I needed. Basically, I purchased an autolevel sensor, but I didn't want to mess up my printer updating the firmware to get the sensor to work. I have heard good stories and horror stories.

With this mod, I really don't need an autolevel. I adjusted all four bed screws using A4 paper to get it level initially (one time). Before every print, I just make sure both carriages on the Z threaded rod are at the same height, and then I adjust the nozzle height with this mod using an A4 paper in the middle to check its height. Turn the dial to raise or lower, and home the Z Axis. Do this until the A4 paper has some resistance but not a lot of resistance. When I mess with the bed to install a mod or something, I have to re-do the four bed screws, but that is it.

I printed the barrel fatty part with the hole side up. I printed the top endstop part with supports.

This mod does go over a chain mod, this one specifically:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1905344

If using a different one, please check to make sure this will fit over it. Also, you might need some spacers/washers behind the bottom part depending on your mod situation.

Hardware needed extra (reuse the endstop switch screws and the bolts and nuts the standard Z endstop uses):

4 x M3 Nuts
3 x M3 Washer
1 x M3 Lock Washer
1 x 40mm long (or longer) M3 Screw (any type head)
2 x M3 Screw (longer screws to fit through this mod, the chain, the carriage, and into the motor)
? x Washer/Spacers (as need be)

Need to know how to melt a nut into PLA/ABS. Screw an M3 nut to the very end of a long M3 screw. Use a lighter to heat up the nut for about 22 to 30 seconds (in the BLUE part of the flame - it can get a black coating if using the orange part). Line the nut up over the plastic part, and using the nut into the PLA/ABS with the hole centered. Push until the nut is all the way in, and it is flat (not tilted). Carefully unscrew the bolt, and let it cool in there.

Construction:

Print one of each of the parts. Melt a nut into the bottom of the thumb wheel (side without numbers). Melt another nut into the fatty endstop cap (the side with the hole).

Slide a nut into the Z endstop top part (the little slot there). Screw the 40mm or longer bolt almost all the way in to that nut on the Z endstop top part (look at the picture to see orientation).

Screw an M3 nut onto the 40mm or longer bolt, followed by a lock washer, followed by a regular washer. Screw on the thumb wheel so the numbers are facing the Z endstop top, and do it ways up the bolt. Finally screw on the end cap fatty part all the way onto the bolt so that it is tight without moving (hand tightening is good enough).

Now, screw the thumbwheel down towards the fatty endcap until it is solidly against it, pretty tight (hand tightening is good enough). Push the washer and lock washer down on top of the thumb wheel. Finally, screw the M3 screw all the way down until it is down solid (use a wrench to tighten, but not over tighten).

Now, you should be able to turn the thumbwheel clockwise or counterclockwise so that the screw head near the slotty nut goes up or down. It should turn fairly easily. Vibration doesn't really change it, and I level it between prints, anyway, so there is no real need to lock it down.

Unlike the other mod this was based off of, do NOT remove the switch arm - it provides a necessary function. When the nozzle head is too close to the bed, you turn the dial so that it pushes the switch arm down a little more (it will bend slightly, and that's fine). When the Z axis is homed, the nozzle will now be raised slight higher. Without the arm, it's not possible to screw it down any more to raise the nozzle - not so good.

Install the top part of the mod as seen in the picture. Install the bottom part of the mod by replacing the current Z endstop and brackets. Be sure that the fatty top part hits the bottom switch end square on. Adjust or use washers/spacers on the bottom part until it does so.

Make sure the carriage isn't over the heated bed when you try leveling initially. Move the thumb wheel until there is about the same amount of bolt space above and below the slotty nut. Set the bottom part to pretty much the bottom. Try homing the Z axis only (again, not over the bed) until it looks like the nozzle is at least 1mm above the bed. THEN and only THEN, try leveling over the bed using an A4 piece of paper.

There it is!

I would like to thank alexan9er and cd1701 for their awesome mods. Without people like them, this mod would not have been possible!

Printer:

Anet A8

A small tufts template to create small bushes using static grass and a static grass applicator.

Print the base and template.
Stick copper tape under the base and solder a small with a hook to connect your static grass applicator. This is optional if you use a metal tray where you connect your static grass applicator.

To create your bushes:

  • Cut to size a piece of oven paper and fit it in the base.
  • Place the mask with the drills on top of the oven paper.
  • Apply PVA glue dots (careful not to touch the walls of the mask).
  • Connect your static grass applicator to the hook.
  • Sprinkle your static grass. 4mm and 6mm works very nicely, a mix of both too.
  • Tap lightly the excess off and repeat if needed.
  • When finished, lift the mask carefully and your tufts will be ready.

If you want to create larger tufts, you can always scale on the X-Y when printing. Remember, you will need a base and the templates.

You will end up with a base and a mask set that can create up to 36 bushes. Under the base, stick copper tape and solder a wire with a hook to connect you static grass applicator's cathode. Applying glue dots in the holes. Careful not to touch the walls. 2 mask widths: 2mm and 2.5mm. They will give you tighter flock.

title: Mean Well power supply bracket for Anet A8

description.text:
UPDATE: I added an inlet/cover design for the LRS350 supply here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2302140

The stock power supply that comes with the Anet A8 is well understood to be a cheap piece of junk. I recommend the Mean Well LRS-350 series supply as a cheap and dependable upgrade, and I recommend buying it from a known distributor such as Mouser to ensure that you get a genuine unit:

http://mouser.com/ProductDetail/Mean-Well/LRS-350-12

However the mounting holes on the LRS supply are different from those on the stock supply. This bracket goes between the power supply and the frame and allows the supply to be mounted to the printer frame in the stock location without any modifications.

You'll need four M4x8, flat head (not pan head!) screws to attach the bracket to the supply - M4x6 is too short, and DO NOT use longer screws or you can short out the guts of the supply. You'll also need three M3x16 or longer flat head screws to attach the bracket to the printer frame, and three M3 nuts (washers also recommended) to secure the M3 screws.

This bracket will fit Mean Well LRS-350, NES-350, SE-350, SP-320 and possibly others.

OpenSCAD design files are attached.

Anet A8

remixed_from.title: Printrbot Simple Fan and LED Mount

title: PrintrBot Simple LED & Fan mount for wooden direct drive extruder

description.text: As I got ready to take a new photo of my Simple with all my modifications I realized I still had my fan and circular LED light jury rigged so I decided that it was time to make a proper mount.
VITAMINS

• 40mm fan w/2 mounting screws/nuts (salvaged from old 1u server)
  • 60mm led light (I got mine @amazon)
    • INSTRUCTIONS

• Print part - no support required

  • Mount fan to part. Insert screws through part, through fan, then attach nut from other side. Tighten well so thing don't vibrate loose.

  • Remove the two screws holding the hotend into the plywood. In my case the hotend remained in place...

  • Insert hotend screws through part, then reinsert in proper position

  • Attach led light to ring using tie-wraps or tape

  • Plug in fan to 3 pin connector at top.

  • Plug in led light. I use the left pin of bed heater for ground and the bottom pin of the e-stop connector for ground.

description.text:
This modular scatter terrain was designed for any tabletop RPG or wargame, or for Discord (FKA Wayfarer Tactics), our fast, modular (as in "fully customizable") miniature gaming rules. If you want to check it out, it's totally free here on our site, so give it a download!. It's scaled for 15mm-18mm scale models, though could work well as dwarven architecture in 28mm/heroic scale. This is an update on our Ruins of Zoth terrain (it's been made easier to print, added more efficient corner pieces, and a doorway/door).

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Discord, and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

title: Probe for surface scanning - CNC machine

description.text:
It took me a couple of prints before I landed on the current design. To make it you obviously need a 3d printer, and in addition some hardware;

  • end stop switch
  • LM8UU bearing
  • 8mm spring
  • 6mm bolt (minimum 40mm length)
  • I also thought about using a 8mm steel rod for the main part going through the bearing but ended up using a 3D printed part instead.

With some rough calculation this probe tool costed me a couple of dollars - max 3 if I also include the 2 failed design prints of the probe tool ☺

The cool thing about this design is that you can perform probing of an uneven surface thus enabling CNC jobs such as cutting or carving to follow the curves of the workpiece. Other probing tools depend on having electric conductive surface tape (e.g aluminium) on the workpiece - this is not needed with the probe tool since it uses a switch instead.

You can read all about the project here: http://diygarageprojects.blogspot.no/2017/03/3d-printed-probe-tool-for-cnc-machine.html

comments.text:
Further observation from my build so far: Can't really use an ITX board with an additional card in this, since there ist no "first" slot, the slot is places at no.2 which is not suitable for an ITX mainboard.
Also, mainboard support is too weak (even with maximum infill) to support an ITX mainboard, and can't be placed far enough back so that the connectors touch the rear. Solved this by building a custom mainboard tray out of 3mm PVC boards. works reasonably well.
Also built a front out of this, since it is still missing in this pack.

title: Inductrix FPV Battery Cap - Flex
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
UPDATE: these are both for batteries with mx connectors

V6 is for the Crazepony 230mah batteries

V3.5 is for the E-lite 200mah batteries.

This is my take on battery caps for the 3.7/3.8v lipo batteries for the Inductrix FPV (what I have) or the tiny whoop (it's my understanding this should work too)

I printed mine in Ninja Flex. Perfect fit really depends on the battery. I used some 200mah batteries as my guide, and they fit nice and snug. But I just got some 230mah batteries, and while they fit fine, but would fall off if you shake them. So print a few, and see how they do for your batteries, then if you need to make them super snug, you can shrink (scale) them a couple of percent.

You can print in one color for charged, and another color for discharged. But I just have one.

If it's charged, it's got a cap on it. If the battery needs a charge, there's no cap.

title: DSA Keycap Set, 8mm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The new home of my DSA keycap project.

This set includes 1u, 1u homing, 1.25u, 1.5u, 1.75u, 2u, 2.25u and 2.75u keys and a 6.25u spacebar.

Mounts are standard MX. The 2u, 2.25u and 2.75u keys have three mounts spaced at 12mm from the center. The 6.25u spacebar has three mounts @ 50mm from the center. Mounts are flush with the bottom of the key so supports shouldn't be necessary.

All keycaps are 18.2mm wide and n*(19mm) - 0.8mm long, where n is the unit length of the key. The height of the key is just under 8mm and the depth of the touch surface is 0.9mm below that. Minimum wall thickness is 1.8mm.

Designed with FreeCad

Revision of Compact Planetary Gearbox by raldrich, I sorted out some tolerance issues I had on the first prints and separated all the pieces since the print has to be really slow and high quality and I can't print for 9 straight hours.
You will need a part of each stl and 3 of the planet_gear.stl to make a whole gearbox. Slow speeds and low layer heights as possible are recommended.
The ratio is 40:9.

BOM as provided by raldrich (I did not print the M6 variation so I won't put that one)

  • M3x12 Socket Head Cap Screw
  • 4 M3 Nut
  • 1 M3x6 Set Screw
  • 4 M3x35 Socket Head Cap Screw
  • 1 M8 Hex Head Cap Screw o
  • 2 608ZZ (8x22x7)
  • 1 M8 or M6 Nylok Nut

After the print, sanding was necessary but the gearbox works overall as expected, I didn't test it at maximum torque yet but it looks promising

comments.author: bigstinker85

comments.text: The stepper will always give you the best torque when moving at a slow angular velocity. See here for a typical curve. If it is precission what you need, you should consider always microstepping first, as the backlash on these 3d printed parts is rather bad. I have tested the gearbox and it can work at full load with no problems. The gearbox works best when finished with slight abrasive. What I did was putting scratch removal cream inside and turned it for 15 minutes. After that it works really smooth. Also, buy good drivers.

print_settings.Notes:: PLA, good cooling

description.text:
Wireless desktop QI charger, designed for Samsung S6, but should be ok for many others with similar dimensions. It needs this module of QI charger:

https://www.aliexpress.com/item/DC-5V-Qi-Standard-Wireless-Phone-Charger-PCBA-Circuit-Board-With-Coil-Wireless-Charging-Micro-USB/32786304209.html

Parts should be printed in PLA without any support (necessary supports are included in the project), but I recommend to use good cooling during printing. Multicolor effect visible on the photo I obtained by changing filament during printing.

Some tips:

  • please remember to remove supports after printing :)
  • coil case should by glued with body, coil cover is mounted only by crowding on case,
  • coil wires are too short, should be extended by at least 0,75mm2 wires,
  • there is no need to glue coil or PCB. Wires are enough for holding it,
  • LED is inside in the body, it's light is visible through the hole, but it looks much nicer after inserting a piece of transparent plastic cylinder (fi3 x 3mm) into this hole,
  • LED originally added by the Chineses is red/blue, it is possible to swap it with any other dualcolor LED (common cathode), but due to other voltage on blue led, after swapping to e.g. red/green, one of colors will be much more intensive. Trimming of it is possible by adding resistor (47-100ohms) in line with brighter led,
  • bottom cover should stick in the body without screws, "on click". But if it is needed, it is possible to screw it with two short(!) screws M3 with small countersunk head. Holes for these screws are covered, so covers should be drilled out,
  • on the bottom of body there are a places for gluing silicone or rubber pads. It is not necessary, but recommended :)
  • for working it needs good quality classic USB charger (>1A) as a power supply. Too weak charger causes oscillation: charging-not charging-charging-not charging.

I'm using this charger from few weeks (with original samsung charger as a power supply), works perfectly :)

title: Blade Inductrix FPV and FPV Pro Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
UPDATE Feb 24, 2018: NEW AND IMPROVED, and some additional options.

STAY TUNED: I have taken a portable plastic storage case from Harbor Freight

https://www.harborfreight.com/20-bin-medium-portable-parts-storage-case-62778.html

And have modified it to fit 2 FPV/FPV Pro's or 2 FPV Plus, or 2 FPV Plus and 4 FPV/Pro's. I will upload a separate project next week. I have the 2 Plus & 4 FPV done, man this thing is sweet. I've uploaded a couple of teaser pictures here.

PLEASE NOTE: I have uploaded an FPV Plus version of the case here:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2801903

I have completely re-worked the files, and optimized for printing. I did a true offset, so now the round corners are parallel. The walls are now 1.6mm or 3.2mm thick, and if you print with 4 shells, they will print solid, and not use infill, which makes them print faster.

I have made a few different versions. I like the thicker walled version, but was also asked to make a thin walled version, which works really well, and reduced print time by more than an hour and a half on my printer.

Here's an explanation of the different versions.

V22 FPV Bottom Thin Half Bat - Thin walled version with battery holders only 1/2 way up. This is enough to hold the battery in place, but further reduces print time. Also made the battery holders a little wider, to hold thicker batteries.

V22 FPV Bottom Thin - Thin walled version without battery holders. This on my printer takes less than 3 hours to print.

V22 FPV Top Thin Lip - New version of a Low profile top, to be used with above version without battery holders

V22 FPV Top Thin Lip Bat - Taller version of the new lid, for the bottom using the 1/2 height battery holders.

V22 FPV Top Thin Lip Tall Bat - Extra tall version of the new lid, for those who want to print the bottom with the battery holders like sebsx, who have really tall batteries.

I have now uploaded the thicker walled versions, with are 1.6mm and 3.2mm thick. The lids have a 10mm overlap, which makes them fit really snug. I like the thicker walled versions for stand alone cases the best, but the thin wall work just fine, and print, much, much faster.

Enjoy.

This is my take on a carry case for an Inductrix FPV.

Design similar to by RockstarAlchemist and babar121

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1580567

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1637219

However, I made this from scratch in Fusion 360.

What I found when I printed the versions above, was for my FPV, the fan cowlings hit the battery compartments. And I really has to press it in, and I worried about warping the fan cowlings. Also the spots for the motors didn't quite line up for mine.

So I just redesigned it to make a little more room. Also, no logos, no fillets for the top and bottom so it prints easier.

author: WindDrake

description.text: I'd like to start off by saying this is not an original idea but rather an improvement on several designs that I saw. Mainly it was the lack of bearings in these designs that motivated me. I also preferred to orient the spool vertically and wanted to remove the excess weight from the top of my printer where it was previously mounted to minimize vibrations. This stand uses four 608 bearings, everything snap fits so no fasteners are required and is designed so that the legs overlap ensuring that even the thinnest spools will work. You can print the bearings (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4676) if you like, I've personally had good results with these in other projects and they would work very well in this application.

100%

Solidworks model and approximate Bill of Materials of a Delta Arm 3D Printer. Assembly size is ~100MB so open in large assembly mode! Based on Werner Berry's BerryBot 3D. Here is Werner Berry's YouTube Channel: http://www.youtube.com/channel/UChZIa-t7aKDU2TE7tAuY3IA Solidworks note: There are 3 mates inside the carriage folder securing the 3 carriages. suppress those 3 mates in the folder and you can move the hot end platform around. Named "Delta Mines" for the university it was used at. Print size: 16'' diameter x 17'' tall.
Estimated cost from scratch: ~$2,500 (Including wire, switches, etc...) Features:
4 nozzle hot end (bowden setup) Water cooled using condensate pump and radiator. heater cartridges are 100vac at 100 watts from McMaster.
nozzle assemblys are secured loosly with a shaft colllar with a plastic insert betweein the tube and set screw to prevent head crashing.
aluminum construction (Aluminum panels and 20mmx20mm aluminum extrusion support framing)
nicrome coil heated circular platform with 2 circuits (large print or small print)
Makerslide vertical members and v-groove sliding carriages
easy calibration
spring loaded heated platform
magnetic ball joints = no backlash --> high accuracy
carbon fiber rods
screw/ worm drive for bowden setup
lazy susan filament spooling. (needs improvement)
acrylic windows with magnetic door latch
electronics in base
removable magnetic display (not shown)
belt driven sliding carriages
ATX power supply powered.
heated bed heat reflector underneath
Eccentric spacer belt tensioner
Vertical columns are easily extendable once Inventables.com gets longer makerslides Suggestions for improvements welcomed. Note: Check my Worm Drive Extruder for bug fixes on that component.
Work in progress.

title: Old Time (before LEGOs) American Plastic Bricks

description.text: My house when my brother and I were young kids was awash in building toys. Coming from a family of engineers and builders, I expected nothing less. I promised myself that when I started fooling around with these 3D printers I would recreate one of my most favorite toys, the American Plastic Bricks. Any internet search will yield a whole lot of information on these toys. Since I fell ill a few months ago, and with a lot of free time on my hands I took out my 6-inch caliper and went to work on faithfully reengineering these bricks. I recreated four out of the many bricks that make up my collection and posted them here. If I have some more free time I will start adding adding more files that make up each set of these bricks. Enjoy.

Printer:

Hictop 3pd-18

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Due to the thin side walls (1.26 mm +/-) and top (.75 mm +/-) the slower the print the better. I been fooling around with different settings on my printer to see which works the best. After a few fails (ok more than a few). I went with a Print Speed of 5 mm/s. I think slower than this would work well too. My basic settings are: Print bed 70 degrees, Filament flow 100% using a PLA filament. I am currently using Cura version 14.12 for printing. Also I am using a support setting of everywhere, for the unmodified bricks this works ok, but not being an expert of every printer I would play around with this setting to see what works for you. The best print orientation for these bricks (for me anyway) is pins down on the print bed, again try a few in different orientations to see what works for you. Also some filing will be needed.

I've included two file for each brick, the mod file is a upgraded brick with a lot of reinforcement added to give the brick some needed support. The other file is the basic brick in its original format. Play around with both and see which one works better for you.

Never say quit....

In hindsight I suppose that some things are more difficult to print (with my printer anyway) then others, these blocks were fun to reengineer but might not translate easily (in their current measurements) into 3D printable things for everyone. Since I don't say " I can't" my thinking is I will have to make them a bit larger and thicker. But if anyone else due to better printers or whatever process you are using, please don't hesitate to email me with the results and a picture. Thanks for giving them a looksee.

title: 9V Battery Cap
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My remake of some similar designs here.

However, I found that those I found here either never fit quite right, or the rings, which connect to the battery would snap off, and I'd have to dig it off the battery.

What I did a little different was to make this with flex filament. Microcenter has their own brand of flex, which is much firmer than Nijaflex, and works really well in this application.

I play in a band, and need to have 9V batteries in my gig bag for my guitars and stomp boxes. These keep the batteries from shorting out, and me having to used cardboard and tape. I tend to print a pile at a clip, and just keep them in a zip lock in my battery drawer.

I also included a version with holes in them so you can text them with a battery tester, without having to take to caps off.

Enjoy.

title: Rocker Switch Housing for 2020 Extrusion / 20mm Switches

description.text:
This small switch box is designed to house a 20mm rocker switch, and mounts to 2020 extrusion. The box wraps around the extrusion, covering two sides. It's secured with a single M4 screw and t-nut, and includes an access hole so an Allen key can be used to tighten the screw. There are a few additional holes included to allow wiring to be routed within the channel on the extrusion. The box is in two parts, and the cover can be secured with M3 screws. The holes in the body are 2.5mm diameter, and I tapped them to M3, although you could probably get away without tapping them and just drive a screw in.

There are plenty of 20mm diameter rocker switches available, but these are the ones I used: https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B01K7MNPB6
You will also need an M4x8 screw, M4 t-nut and two M3x10 screws for attaching the cover.

To assemble: start by feeding the wires into the box and out through the large hole in the front. Position an M4 t-nut in the extrusion channel and offer the box up to the extrusion. Insert an M4x8 screw into the screw hole, align it with the t-nut, and tighten it with an Allen key inserted through the access hole. Wire up the switch before pushing the switch into the housing.

If you wanted multiple switches, it would be possible to stack several of these together on the extrusion.

Printer:

Anycubic Kossel Linear

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height, 0.8mm shell thickness

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed the housing with supports generated by Cura, but you might get away without using supports. The cover doesn't need supports, obviously.

author: peaberry

description.text:
This is more of an "I made one" than a remix, but I spent some time repairing the STL of the head (with makeprintable.com) and so I've included that file in case other folks find it useful. Please see laurent_despeyroux's lovely source design for the other files:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1619667
Thanks very much Laurent for the fun design.

I printed everything at 0.1mm/layer, scaled to about half the size that Laurent used. Miraculously, the tongue stayed attached when I removed the supports -- but this print is intended as a toy gift for a child and so I expect the tongue to come off quite quickly.

I used the following scale for each piece:

head: 255%

37 segments: from 246.5% down to 110.5%, decreasing by 3.5% between each segment

tail: 107%

One other note is that I printed the head at a bizarre angle: 45 degree tilt and with the top of the head facing down. This was so that I only needed supports from the bed. I originally tried it completely upside down, but the PLA was weak around the "arms" of the ball socket and it broke when I tried to insert it.

description.text: I found that my old Wieder wieght set had broken nuts/bolts that hold the wieghts on the bars. This is a replacement.

Printer:

DaVinci 1.0 / Repetier

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

bolt: 100% nut:30%

Notes:

You can print without supports but it looks better with them.
The nut part should be at least 20% infill with 3 outer layers, 7 top/bottom layers, while the bolt should be solid. I printed one in PETG which is the strongest but I also used ABS. If the bolt isn't solid it will snap with any sideways force. 100% infill for the bolt.

ABS doesn't supply much friction on the steel bar but it does hold. If it doesn't you could use a bit of tape on the bar and then slip the bolt on the bar and tighten it down.

author: rtarrant

title: Hypercube 8mm XY 10mm Z STLs in one place

description.text:
This thing is simply my build log for the Hypercube by Tech2C, and a "facilitator" for everyone that want to build the Hypercube with some typical modifications:

  • 8mm steel rods for X and Y
  • 10mm steel rods for Z.

A video of my build: https://youtu.be/mxuwtkStnhI

In the original thing page, under comments, someone posted an Excel BOM.
I took it, modified, added some sheets:

  • a 3D printed parts checklist and completion calculator
  • a torque calculator for motors
  • some options with size.
  • the BOM with link to shops and prices to give an idea on how much a prusa i3 conversion will cost.
    Please use it at your own risk!!!

I do not want to take ownership or redistribute files, please look at the original sources for details. Hope this is fine for everyone involved. All authors cited, if someone is missing or upset, drop me a message.

For any comment or question about the Hypercube, I suggest to post to:
http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/hypercube-3d-printer

Build change log

*March, 31, 2017" - Build can be considered as almost finished. See the pic of the vase.. :-)
Added spool holder (by henryarnold) see references below to get files.
Next modification will be power supply mount and a better board mount. Anyway, now it prints.

March, 26, 2017 - First print done, calibration done. Everything is perfect. Vibration was an issue but then I used my dampening feets. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1548808
I also redesigned the front bed support to use two screws. I strongly suggest this modification (Bed_support_front.stl).
Also added caps for 20x20 extrusions. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2204965

March, 21, 2017 - I found it is quite difficult for the endstop on X carriage to be engaged unless it is really close to the XY idler. If you're worried by crashes like me, just print any 8mm clamp like this one and put it on the smooth rod a little bit before. Maybe I'll found a bettere solution in th future.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:71488

March, 19, 2017 - It took two full days to go from scratch to first movement.
Needed to print bed support v1.1a & 1.1b (one left, one right) since my 285 extrusions are a little bit too short.
Z end-stop design of choice is far from being perfect, but did not found a better solution yet.
Firmware: MarlinKimbra MK4duo 4.3.1 http://marlinkimbra.it/

March, 12, 2017 - all parts printed. Waiting for Alu profiles and rods to arrive.

Printer:

pruisa i3 kit

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

PETG
0.5 nozzle
1.5 mm Perimeters
0.8 top/bottom layers

Nothing special except for the X carriage, the space for the LM10UU are a little bit too short. A sharp knife is the maker's best friend.

Nut captive locks in the Z carriage for M3 nuts on borders aren't so tight. Probably the design should be reviewed.

Key design choices
  • X carriage: remixed by me from arturslab, with holes mount compatible with i3 rework and a custom extruder mount from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2157979
  • X carriage LM8UU clamp by micvee: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1771522
  • XY dual bearing joiner for 8mm roads by jinx: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1874781
  • Z carriage for 10 mm rods by henryarnold: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1950819

print_settings.Notes:: I chose to use supports because the holes for the screws is only 6.5mm in diameter. I haven't tried it without the supports.

description.text:
I figured that I would create a new style of spinner that I haven't seen on this site. The center ring is held in place by the 3 screws. This one uses (3) 1/4" nuts, (3) 1/4"x1" screws and one 608 bearing.

This design is a little thicker and heavier than a normal spinner, but it's still manageable. The center ring is 9mm tall (ball bearing is 7mm). The ring has 3 recessed areas so that the screws will go into and help hold the center ring in place. The outer piece is 11.5mm thick. I made it that way so that the screw heads wouldn't stick out too far.

This design is about 3" in diameter.

The design is in two pieces so you can print the center ring a different color if you choose.

Edit: I've uploaded models that use #10 screws instead of the 1/4" screws. It makes the spinner an overall thickness of 9mm.

title: Dual head Calibration Plate - Checker board

description.text:
This is a checker board pattern for helping to confirm calibration of a dual head printer. It will test XY axis alignment as well as ooze control for the idle head.

The pattern of colors reverse during the second half of the print to give a third direction of reference for adjustments.

The two parts are Cura scaled and oriented for printing. With the two parts loaded in the print space you select Dual Extrusion Merge and the parts will combine as a single print with two colors. Whichever part is loaded first will be the primary head and the second one will be the other.

For best results use calibrated filament. You can find calibration clips for printers that can hold a 0.1mm tolerance or better here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1037301 I use these clips to calibrate my filaments as shown in the images.

Printer:

ReliaBuild 3D Dual (RB3 Dual)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used an ooze shield around the print. Retraction settings for particular filaments will vary and may need to be adjusted.

I figured that I would create a new style of spinner that I haven't seen on this site. The center ring is held in place by the 3 screws. This one uses (3) 1/4" nuts, (3) 1/4"x1" screws and one 608 bearing.

This design is a little thicker and heavier than a normal spinner, but it's still manageable. The center ring is 9mm tall (ball bearing is 7mm). The ring has 3 recessed areas so that the screws will go into and help hold the center ring in place. The outer piece is 11.5mm thick. Printer Brand:

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

Notes:

I chose to use supports because the holes for the screws is only 6.5mm in diameter. I haven't tried it without the supports.

This is my second attempt at a 3d printable Torqbar. The first one that i made (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2121893) fits the standard skateboard bearings but does not have same dimensions as the real Torqbar. I tried to make this one as close to the real thing as possible, which means i couldn't fit a standard skateboard bearing.

This spinner requires one MR95ZZ (5x9x3mm) bearing (not the standard skateboard bearing!). You can get these super cheap from Aliexpress or similar sites.

Please share your results is you decide to print the model :)

One thing to keep in mind when printing, is that the caps are concave. So the face of the caps should be up (like in the picture) to prevent your printer messing up the cap's face with support material.

title: 3DTouch Sensor adapter for e3d clamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If You want to use this e3d Mount You can use that adapter for Your 3DTouch sensor - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1695758

And there is a front part - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2172476

!!! Hole its not square, check it please before forcing sensor in it !!!

!!! its 18mm version !!!

If anyone need the sensor like this You can order GENUINE 3DTouch sensor here : http://ali.pub/ldh23

Or GENUINE BLTouch if You prefer is here: http://ali.pub/1f5veq

Or cheapest one here : http://ali.pub/1h7ghd

Later I try to remix that e3d mount for proper 3dtouch mounting point.

PS. my parts in action ;) - https://youtu.be/cJ1K7rZsdtY
PS2 . sendor in action :) - https://youtu.be/HdLyox9N8CE

==============================================================================================================================================

==================================================================================================================================

!!! ALL THANKS GOING TOO - http://www.thingiverse.com/OderWat/about !!!
!!! OderWat IS THE ONE THAT MAKE IS POSSIBLE !!!

It uses the "LED pin" which is an unused pin on the A8 (using the stock 5 button 2004 LCD). That is the third wire counted from below (where the red marker is on the cable). I simply spliced the cable and cut that wire. This will be the servo signal (yellow).

On the A6, you may use wire no. 10 (the one on the other side to the red marked wire) and pin 17 in firmware the but you will lose the buzzer. I think one could use wire no. 7 and FW pin 29 but I could not yet verify that because I don't have an A6 display available.

The +5V (red) and GND (brown/black) are available at the z-end-stop connector as is the signal itself (white).

You can simply connect the black and brown wire of the sensor to the GND from the z-end-stop socket. This leaves you with 4 instead of 5 wires from the sensor to the board. On the first of the second two images you can see how I used some patch cables and a wire clamp to draft the connection at the board. In the second of the two images you can see the wiring at the sensor.

After everything worked well I have chosen an old usb mouse cable. Those have exactly 4 wires. I used green for the sensor, red for +5v, black for GND and yellow for the servo signal (originating from the LCD cable). I crimped a fitting connector for the z-end-stop socket and a single connector for the connection to the spliced LCD cable. I also soldered the other end of those 4 wires directly to the PCB inside of the sensor. Soldering is not needed and can be a pain. Beware not to destroy your sensor if you do it. You can see the result in the last three images.

Setting up SkyNet3D / Marlin (the firmware) is pretty straightforward. Besides the entries for the auto bed levelling you need to make the following entries:

define BLTOUCH

define SERVO0_PIN 27

define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -20

define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -15

define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0

define Z_MIN_PROBE_ENDSTOP_INVERTING false

I also used:

define Z_CLEARANCE_DEPLOY_PROBE 5

define Z_CLEARANCE_BETWEEN_PROBES 5

define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 20

define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 200

define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 20

define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 200

After mounting and uploading the new firmware you can test you sensor:

M280 P0 S10 ; pushes pin down
M280 P0 S90 ; drags pin up
M280 P0 S120 ; does selftest (pin up/down continuously)

M280 P0 S160 ; reset alarm

M280 P0 S60 ; switch triggering test mode
; move pin at the sensor up or down manually
M119 ; reports state of the endstop
; pin up (LED on) z_min should read TRIGGERED
; pin down (LED off) z_min should read open
If your sensor does not selftest but blinks directly or after some few alternating motions you need to adjust the screw in the top of the sensor. One of the allen wrenches which are part of the printer does fit right in. Lose the screw until the light went off, then fasten the screw until it is lit again. I needed some time to find the sweet sport. Using selftest and reset alarm until it worked well.

Finally you can try a G28 command. If everything is OK it will probe twice in the middle of the bed. The tip will go down and up again as soon it touches the surface of the bed. If not you need to check cables and settings.

To adjust the z offset I use the following easy and pretty failsaife procedure:

; preheat for working temperatures
(M502 ; optionally reset to firmware settings)
M851 Z0 ; reset any z-offset
G28 ; home all
G1 X110 Y110 ; move nozzle in center
; now move your nozzle manually onto the bed such that it (strongly) grips paper.
G92 Z0 ; tell the printer that this is Z = 0
G30 X110 Y110 ; move the sensor over the center and let it trigger
; note what z position G30 reports, that, negated, is your z offset
M851 Z-1.23 ; register that z offset (here 1.23 as example)
M500 ; store those values into the EEPROM
You may want to do some G30 X110 Y110 commands to validate how well your sensor works. It should report the same values +/- 0.0x.

You can also enable Z_MIN_PROBE_REPEATABILITY_TEST in the firmware and use M48 L10 P8 V4 to let it test repeatability at the same point with a lot of fake movement in between probes.

There are occasions where the sensor after power on gives an error with the G28 command for no obvious reason. I found that the sequence:

M280 P0 S160 ; Reset 3D-Touch
G4 P500
M280 P0 S10 ; Pin out
G4 P500
M280 P0 S90 ; Pin back
G4 P500
Before the G28 command will reset the sensor in a way that it will alway (tm) work.

UPDATE: I added an alternative design "Distant" for the excellent "Mistral 2" cooling fanduct. This needs slightly changed firmware settings as follows:

define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -26

define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 200

No

100%
