title: Replacement gear for L.L. Bean mini crank 3 LED flashlight

description.text:
A few years ago, one of my L.L. Bean mini-crank 3 LED flashlights broke. I own several because I hate using disposable batteries.
I could no longer wind the crank to charge the flashlight. After taking it apart, I found that the center gear had some teeth broken off. I always figured that I could fix it somehow. So I put it away for another day.
Years later, I get my 3D printer, and figure that now is my chance. I take measurements off the broken gear, and using the gear add-on in Blender, I was able to make something that looked very close. The outer teeth were perfect, but the inner teeth did not quite come out right due to their small size. I made a few adjustments, and finally got a gear that worked smoothly after about three tries. I fixed it!
Amazingly, after about a month, one of the other flashlights broke in the same way. I simply got the STL file from before, and printed out another new gear.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The small size of the teeth on the inner gear made it difficult to have them come out with the correct size due to the resolution of my printer/slicer combination. I just made them larger and longer until what came out of the printer worked.
Blender gear addon. I was able to get the necessary measurements off the damaged gear.

author: msadler2

description.text:
A friend had been wanting a Grenade. I had seen a few designs already, and really liked some, but wanted to add some additional functionality. 
Not to completely reinvent the wheel, I incorporated a few of those designs and made the thing modular.
After many Boolean operations, and due to poor planning, I accidentally created a locking feature with a ridge on the opening of the grenade body.
I got griped at for taking this into a public place.. I really didn't consider that either..

I'm a bit paranoid about overhangs and bridges, so I actually rotated the top 180 before printing. Just added the file top_tall_safe_fixed It has been rotated and scaled properly. The prior version was under size by a factor of 10... The body needs no modification before printing. One of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10718 will need to be printed and attached using a ~4x10+ screw. There are additional instructions for spring loading and a pin for that thing... It will also have the aperture logo on the back, which may or may not be desirable (one reason for modularity...)

title: Bridge, retract and acceleration test - Lightweight

description.text: This is a lightweight model that prints quickly that I designed to help tune bridge, acceleration, jerk and retract settings on my printer.

comments.text: How would someone go about useing this to tune?
comments.author: marcbea

comments.text: Print it out with the two cylinders pointed upwards.  For bridge settings, look for sagging in the middle.  The two cylinders should be parallel.  For retract settings look for blobbing and stringing between the cylinders.  For acceleration look at the edges to make sure there is no ringing.

description.text:
I was testing them for a weeks, everything is alright on my printer.
!!! Bed goes slightly down, check Your printer frame clearance before You turn printer on !!!

Print on the side when holes are closer to hot bed!

After print there is a small lip on that side (hot bed side), to hold IGUS bearing on place. Trim it a little as much as Your bearings need, its different on every printer and settings (DONT TRIM IT ALL THE WAY, they holding bearings in place) and then push bearings in untill they snap in place. Use some force to do it :)

remixed_from.title: Simple Iphone and Ipad stand for Apple wireless keyboard and trackpad

description.text: Let's face it, most of us have enough computing power in our pocket to do 98% of our daily work. Recently I realized that most of the work I do is in the terminal these days with a bit of email. This means a tablet (iPad mini and my Nexus 4 phone in this case) loaded with iSSH would be the perfect lightweight travelling machine if only it had a decent keyboard. I tried to find a keyboard for my iPad Mini that had a decent touch but they were all junk. Also, I find that I type better if I use the same keyboard for everything. The Apple bluetooth wireless keyboard is a personal favourite so I opted to created a little holder. This one fits the iPad mini and the Nexus 4 phone in its upright position. This way I can tap out a long email on my phone if I need to as well. Note: Nexus 4 + iPad mini is a pretty specific pairing so I created a version that's just for the ipad mini (basically just the same thing without the little notch.

title: Apple iPod Shuffle (4th Gen) holder for work badge lanyard

description.text:
My 4th Generation iPod Shuffle's clip was not large enough to fully clip onto my work badge lanyard, so I created a holder that slides onto the lanyard and holds the Shuffle snug as a bug in a rug.

After using it for about a month, I added a hole in the bottom so that crumbs do not accumulate in the bottom of the holder. I am a piggie.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print it vertically so that it does not need supports, and the box is stronger. I made the case snug. I also made the slide snug. This was so that my Shuffle would stay in place.

Put it on your lanyard by feeding one cord in at a time, pushing off to the side so that the other cord can fit. It helps to pull the cord tight and work it in back and forth. It is snug, but it does slide up and down once both sides are in. If you want to make it easier to take on and off, you can enlarge the slide part (but it will be less secure)

I first made a rectangular cube that was the exact size of the shuffle, and then built that box around that. I gave it no tolerance. When the part is printed vertically, the walls are strong enough to flex just a bit, and hold the Shuffle in place nicely.

title: Fan duct for active cooling, supportless, parametized OpenSCAD

description.text:
OpenSCAD source code for a supportless, parameterized fan duct that is currently configured to fit an E3D v5 hot end and a Prusa i3 reworked Wades extruder from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:119616.
Please bear in mind this is my first OpenSCAD program, and the first 3D object I have designed using any sort of CAD software, so there will be scope for improvement!
Source also available at https://github.com/spinorkit/FanDuctOpenSCAD
Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:63123
Uses:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18273, thanks doommeister, and
http://svn.clifford.at/openscad/trunk/libraries/shapes.scad, thanks Catarina Mota.
Print without support in ABS.
Before printing, set, at least, the parameter to the value you use for printing. Update: added the file FanductOvalJHead45.stl, which is configured for a J-Head with a vertical distance of 45mm from the bed to the center of the mounting bolt. Update: added the files FanductOvalE3dv6PrusaReworkv4.stl and FanductOvalE3dv6.scad for the E3D v6 . This stl should be printed with 0.2 mm layer height.

Measure the mountToHotEndBottomZ parameter (in mm) by homing the z axis and measuring the vertical distance from the bed to the center of the mounting hinge, as shown in the photo.
Also measure the mountToFilamentHoriz parameter as shown in the photo to ensure the vents will be positioned symmetrically around the nozzle.
Print in ABS without support.
I used Cura with 0.4 nozzle, 0.25 layer height, 0.8 shell thickness,0.75 bottom/top thickness, 20% fill, bed temp 110, and brim platform adhesion.
For the E3D v6 version, use 0.2 layer height.

Is there any certain flag(s) I can use to extrude a 2D object and bend it?  If You can give me some leads, I will study only those and make my design much quicker.  I just need a little bit of direction.
comments.author: JunkYardDawg

comments.text:
The sweep module from here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:900137 lets you generate a polyhedron from an array of polygons. In this example the polygons are generated by a function giving the shape of the NACA family of airfoils, but this set of modules and functions will work with any 2D shape specified as a list of points. You could experiment with this example to get a feel for how to do what you want in OpenSCAD.
Alternatively, you might like to try https://www.onshape.com/. I don't use it myself yet, but it looks powerful.

comments.text:
Sorry, I only just realized you posted a screen shot of openscad with the fan duct file open.
So, to answer your question, the gap between the cones and the rest of the model is mainly a result of the layerHeight parameter being set to 1 mm in the scad source. I set it to that to speed up the F5 rendering while tweaking the design parameters. Before hitting F6 in preparation for generating the STL you should set the layerHeight parameter to the value you use for printing (I now use 0.2 mm for these fan ducts). The F6 rendering at 0.2mm takes about 42 minutes on my Core I7.

comments.text:
I uploaded an stl for a version configured for 45mm. This changed the shape quite considerably and I have not printed it, so no guarantees! I tweaked a few other parameters to try and improve the airflow, but these are also untested.
To measure where the airflow is centered, swing the duct back away from the nozzle and use your finger to sense where it is strongest. Mark that position on the duct and with the duct back in position, measure the horizontal distance from the mark to the center of the mounting bolt. This parameter can then be set in the SCAD file to center the airflow on the nozzle.

5V buzzer cap used for quadcopters. Mute annoying beep sounds while at home just testing, without using tape to cover it. There's a hole at the side to let air escape when capping, but offset from the center to still cover the buzzer hole and mute the sound. Print using TPU filament for best results.

print_settings.Notes:: I use a 20mm brim to keep the part sticking to the plate, should use ABS or PETG, PLA probably won't like the heat. You will need a 14-1/4" 8MM guide rod, I used the one left over from my Lawsy carriage upgrade, and an LM8UU linear bearing, also left over from my upgrade. You will also need 2 x15mm M3 Screws and 2 M3 nuts. Push the screws up through the bottom clamp, put the nuts into the cavities in the top bracket, then loosely attach the clamp to the bracket. Push the rod onto the bottom anchor, snap the LM8UU bearing into the end of the Top Bracket, it should fit tightly and stay in place due to the two inside ridges. Then slide the bearing onto the rod, and cap the other end of the rod with the other anchor. Finally, insert the slots in the two anchors onto the frame of the Solidoodle at an angle, putting the top one closest to the left vertical frame, then sliding the bottom one on from the right. Adjust until they are close to the left vertical frame and as straight as you can get the rod. I just eyeballed it to start. They should be fairly tight, and should not move without a bit of pressure. Slide the bracket up until you can clamp the bracket onto the aluminum build surface support, then tighten the 2 screws. Run the build plate up and down in the Z axis, adjusting the anchors so that the bearing slides freely. If everything is lined up, the bracket should keep the end of the build plate from wobbling back and forth, and should run up and down with no resistance. In the photo I included, you can see I just keep the anchors in place with some tape. Once I am sure of the position I'll drill holes through the anchors and screw them into permanent position. So far it is working like a charm, the build plate is rock solid and moves freely up and down. If you notice the bracket flexing or catching as it moves vertically then you may not have the anchors adjusted right. You can also loosen the clamp to adjust it's position.

description.text:
I notice a lot of wobble from side to side in the build plate as the print head changes direction, and I think it affects the quality of the print. After upgrading my carriages to the Lawsey carriages, I had some extra LM8UU bearings, and also the X and Y guide rods, since I had upgraded to hardened rods for the new carriages. I used one of the bearings and one of the Y Guide rods to stabilize the bed so it could not move from side to side.
Working like a champ!

Finally, insert the slots in the two anchors onto the frame of the Solidoodle at an angle, putting the top one closest to the left vertical frame, then sliding the bottom one on from the right. Adjust until they are close to the left vertical frame and as straight as you can get the rod. I just eyeballed it to start. title: Rick Sanchez (Rick and Morty) Mask Remix
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE: 9/27/2017, Original mouth (remix_Mouth.stl) determined to have been corrupted upon uploading to Thingiverse. I have replaced it with remix_Mouth_2.stl. Anyone with files downloaded before 9/27 is advised to obtain the new version of the mouth before printing.

This is a remix of easilyused's totally awesome Rick Sanchez mask. Be sure to check out his page (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1861871) for more info.

After printing and assembling a mask with his files, I decided to combine many of the pieces and optimize them for a 220x220 bed (his being optimized for a ~200x200 printing surface). I also added small tabs on the interior of some pieces to assist in aligning them properly, which should make assembly easier and provide increased surface area for the glue joint.

With this remix, the majority of the front of the mask consists of 4-5 pieces, as opposed to 11, while keeping supports to a minimum. This cleans up the look of the assembled mask by eliminating many of the seams on the face. I hollowed the tongue, and left the eyeballs and rear section of the mask unmodified.

This remix includes two different options for the face, depending on the limit of your Z-axis:
1) The "FaceForehead225" file is a one-piece face and forehead that is 225mm tall.
2) The other option is using the separate "Face" and "Forehead" files included.

Note: (7/2017) Added a separate eyebrow file, as per a request.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I didn't print the mask that I've assembled from these particular files, but easilyused's print settings should apply:

Resolution: Any
Rafts: No, used 5mm brim instead
Supports: Yes
Infill: 100%

Loctite Ultra Gel Control works well at bonding pieces together. But, if you don't want to have to hold it for 5 minutes, apply it and then give it 10-20 seconds of air-time and it will want to bond quickly. Also, I would recommend JB Weld Plastic Bonder for the seams. Perhaps extrude some beads of it, and use the Loctite just to get the pieces to bond quickly while the epoxy sets up. This method might be less tedious than applying some kind of filler (spackle, bondo, wood filler, rock hard, etc.) to the surface afterward (unless you want to smooth out the entire mask), as all that would need removing would be the excess epoxy from the exterior surface.

PLA is soft compared to some filler materials so, unless you cover the whole surface, it can be a chore to blend/transition all of the seams while achieving a consistent surface texture. The less filler you need, the better; and aligning the pieces properly is crucial to minimizing the amount of filler required.

Top Tip: Don't get THE cheapest paint, as it is priced by the amount and quality of the pigment it contains. Cheaper paints require more coats for adequate coverage (even spending an extra 50 cents on Folk Art instead of the Michael's brand 'Craft Smart' showed a marked improvement in my tests). This mask is larger than photos make it appear, so if you intend to paint the whole thing by hand then you'll want to do it the least number of times as possible. And remember to mix enough of each color you'll need all at once, because you might not be able to mix the exact same color(s) for subsequent coats.

comments.text: So I loaded some parts up in Simplify3D and noticed some issues I cant figure out. The mouth piece is technically two separate pieces. There is a split down the center through the entire model. When sliced it basically prints two pieces with an extremely tiny gap in between. Am I missing something?
comments.author: anthonyburton

comments.text: That's odd, since I took steps to avoid that very problem. I had heard of an occasional issue with TinkerCad where objects being grouped together would have a micro-gap between them unless they overlapped. So, when making the chin, I stretched the left and right chin pieces towards the center by ~.1 mm so they overlapped before grouping them. Some people have noticed a seam, others haven't, so I think it's a software thing. If your gap looks about .2 mm, then I'd guess Simplify3D is reading that overlap as a gap.
comments.author: anthonyburton

comments.text: Great tips. So I found a solution. Basically I used the "Separate Connected Surfaces" option in S3D. It separated the two "halves" of the chin, then I moved them closed to the middle by .1 mm. Sliced and no gap at all. Ran it through the slice preview and the toolhead showed no separation between the two pieces. Where's the best place to upload these to get them to you?
comments.author: NubeGoldberg

comments.text: Glad to hear you have it worked out. You can upload it (as a Remix, I guess) here on Thingiverse. I can then download it and put a copy with my files, as well as create a link to your page.

comments.author: rgamble84

comments.text: It's funny, at first you think, "All of this 1.5mm stuff will print in no time..." but then it turns into a week. Sorry to hear about the supports issue. I had a similar problem on a couple of pieces, especially the nose, but not to the extent that it compromised the print. There were obvious localized layer adhesion issues due to the supports "leaving a bunch of strings" (for lack of a better term) when transitioning from printing supports to printing the actual piece. The stringy bits would get dragged into/across the piece, causing the problems. I tried messing with print temps, retraction length/speed, and various supports settings in the slicer; but it didn't help much. Obviously something I need to look into further. I ended up backing the areas with the epoxy I mentioned in the description and I was good to go.
comments.author: rgamble84

comments.text: no gap or anything,  It came out smooth.  Some pieces on the hair seemed like there was a seem.  I was hoping for an entire eye instead of half.  I'll try to piece it together myself.  Thinking about putting a coat of fiberglass to make it more durable.
comments.author: NubeGoldberg

comments.text: The shape of the full eyeballs don't lend themselves well to printing. They'd require supports in one way or another, and maybe even a raft. For my purposes, I didn't find the extra filament required to be worth it. If you wanted to try to print them whole, I could join them and upload another file, but it'd definitely be faster/easier to print as is. Especially if supports were causing you problems.
comments.author: rgamble84

comments.text: Can most of this be printed without supports?  Just seems like there isn't much overhang on something like the chin.  Just looking to save time.  Day 2...
comments.author: rgamble84

comments.text: I would recommend supports for everything, just to be safe since pieces are so thin. I'd imagine one could get away with not using supports for the tongue, and some/all of the hair spikes. The mouth is a giant overhang, so it definitely needs it. Maybe consider adjusting the settings in your slicer (if possible) so it only prints support for areas that are steeper than a given angle (probably auto set to 45-50 degrees).
comments.author: rgamble84

comments.text: Tong didn't need supports, the mouth did.  Finishing other half of the face today.  Doesn't look like there's much overhang Looking it's going to be a 48 hr run time.  Wondering if the side pieces to the hair would need support.  It would save about six hours of build time
comments.author: NubeGoldberg

comments.text: If you're doing the upper half of the face I think the tops of the eye-holes, the eye brow, the nose, and the ears might need supports. To save time/material maybe try manually adding specific areas for supports rather than have the slicer automatically decide where supports are placed. Also then consider adjusting the settings in the slicer so that supports separate easier, rather than be sturdier, making it easier to achieve a cleaner look on the exterior of the mask.

author: NubeGoldberg

print_settings.Notes:: Make sure that the supports only go inside the link with the two holes and the bridge.  If you get support in the small groove of the pin, it can be difficult, but not impossible to remove.

description.text:
I wanted to do something with snap together parts, and this idea somehow bubbled up.

It turns out to be a wonderful fidget. Fidget wise, I prefer keeping the chain as a line instead of linking it into a circle.

ALERT: For those that keep the chain as a line, I have provided a little end support because the open link on one end tends to get damaged.

I experimented with the teeth on the pin part. At this size, each part length = 2.54 cm, the teeth design works nicely. None of my chains have come apart and that is with extensive fidgeting. When I scaled this up two times, the teeth were too rigid, and some of them broke off putting it together. So bottom line, if you are going to scale this, you may want to change the teeth design, and tolerances.

PRO TIP: If you print out a set to give away, DO NOT put the chain together. Let them do it. :)

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The small annular rings on the pin are angled so that they do not need support.

Make sure that the supports only go inside the link with the two holes and the bridge. If you get support in the small groove of the pin, it can be difficult, but not impossible to remove.

print_settings.Notes:: No rafts for the top, how ever you will should use a raft for the cylinder. Printing at these settings will take around 30-40 hours depending how fast you print. I chose to print at 50mm/sec and it took 34 hours for the shade and 3 hours for the top. You may not need the L brackets, as you can just set the shade on the previous shade and rest the top on top of the previous shade top. If you don't want to do that and want more light coming out of your lamp, you can cut the original lamp shade up about an inch or so and glue the brackets inside on the top of the new shade. Also the lamp doesn't come with the light bulbs, you can use what ever ones you want but they should be led so it doesn't melt the PLA if you use that type of plastic. And make sure your pictures aren't too dark/bright when making the lamp shade, if they are, you may not see them and or it will look bad. Anyways good luck!

description.text:
This is a cheap IKEA lamp hack that requires a large printer (~200mm). Using this $5 lamp and these $3 lights
http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/20055421/
http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/70326571/
I was able to create nice lithophane lamps for my friends and family.

First off you will need to create the shade, go to this website

http://maker.dongguk.edu/webclient/cylinder_litho_index.html

upload a few pictures, choose your resolution and thickness. I stuck with .75 base thickness, smoothing 5, 1.0 font thickness (didnt end up having any text) with an Inner radius of 94 (188 Diameter all together so your printer must be at least 190-200mm in Diameter).

Then for the top, I provided a plain top (187mm in diameter), how ever if you customize it using some Lithophane prints, make yours here

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:74322

and here is the top on tinkercad

https://www.tinkercad.com/things/2FaJk5ip8IR

then resize them using tinkercad and or 3Dbuilder (default windows app)
I took this top and just placed the lithophanes on top and grouped them together then printed them out using cura.

Anet A8

You may not need the L brackets, as you can just set the shade on the previous shade and rest the top on top of the previous shade top. description.text:
Another go at a fountain nozzle that emits a circular curtain of water. This is a different design to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2170816 and is quite functional. This one seems less likely to gum up with gunk - but I need to run it a few days to be sure.

This prints in two parts which are glued together with CA glue. Be careful when gluing to make sure the inner part is perfectly aligned with the outer or the spray will be lopsided.

Printable without support or raft and much quicker than my other fountains to print (1hr on my machine).

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm layers

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Be sure to print the bottom piece rotated 180 degrees, as the flat surface is at the top of the model (sorry...)

Looking around at commercially available fountain nozzles I saw one that produces the sort of stream I was after. I modelled it in Fusion 360 as a couple of revolved solids, with some support vanes (3) to locate the inner piece.

I think I will probably modify these vanes as they are the most likely part to collect goo, and I probably need to make them more of a press fit as they printed a little loose on my machine. To resolve this one could very slightly scale up the inner part when slicing. I think it would be better to have more of them than just 3 too.

remixed_from.author: photonix
remixed_from.title: directional YAGI WLAN Antenna EXTENSION for 2.4 GHz

description.text:
This is a derivative of Photonix's YAGI frame. I converted from STL to DWG and then traced out the spots that needed cutting. It does not have letters or numbers on it, only the basic cuts that are functional.
Please see the original http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19548

Cut on a laser cutter from 1/8" (3mm) plexiglass. I've made some from 1/4" plywood which also works well, but probably wouldn't hold up if exposed to outdoor conditions for an extended period. You want to place the center of this object at the point on the rubber-duckie that is where the center conductor of the coax emerges from the shield. I pulled the cover off the antenna to make sure where this spot was, then the cover snapped back on with no ill effects. This is a plain DXF, so it should be a simple matter to customize to your needs. The large hole is where the rubber-duckie antenna goes. This one is sized for a D-Link brand antenna from a DWL-800 Access point. You may need to adjust the diameter of this hole to get a snug fit at the proper height for your particular antenna. Also you'll need to adjust the size of the holes for the copper wire. This will be very dependent on the material you cut from and from the properties of your laser cutter. Here are some sizes that worked well for me, giving a "press fit". AWG...........Wire.............Crosssection.
Size.......Dia(mm)............Area(mm^2).......Hole Size(mm)
17...............1.17..................1.04...................1.05
14...............1.65..................2.08...................1.45
12...............2.05..................3.31...................1.85 (3mm Plexiglass)
12...............2.05..................3.31...................1.70 (6mm Plywood) The first photo shows my latest effort which is built on a plexiglass frame with 12-gauge wire. The 2nd photo shows one cut from plexiglass with 17 ga wire elements. The third photo shows the rubber-duckie antenna disassembled and mid-line point marked. Last photo shows a 1/4" plywood antenna reassembled and yagi frame attached over proper spot. No reflective or directive elements are shown in yagi frame to simplify the photo, just the antenna and the frame. The DXF file that has two frames in it has the holes sized for 17 gauge wire. The DXF that has three frames in it has the holes sized for 12 gauge wire. The DXF file with the holes is a calibration piece to test what size hole will make a tight fit on the wire you have. The holes are in 0.05 increments from 1.0 to 2.2 mm diameter. The units for all of the DXF files is millimeters. I added another photo of one made with 12-gauge wire. I like this one much better because the wire is stiffer and straighter to begin with, and it's easier to keep it straight. I used a BASIC program written by DL6WU (amateur radio callsign) to calculate the element lengths for 12-gauge wire. Another advantage of thicker wire is that the bandwidth will be a little wider. I cut the wires about 0.5 - 1.0 mm longer than called for, then used a sharpening stone to hone down the wire length to within 0.1 mm using a vernier caliper - see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26258. Once I inserted each wire, I used a ruler to get each wire centered in the frame (say, within 0.5 mm). Here is a table of the wire lengths I used for 12-gauge wire: 59.1.......reflector
50.9.......1st director
50.1.......2nd director
49.3.......3rd director
48.6.......4th director
47.9.......5th director The positions of the directors and reflector matched up very well with the program output so I didn't change any of the hole locations from the original design by Photonix. It makes a noticeable improvement, but I don't have the resources to measure the gain provided by this antenna, so I would be interested in hearing from anyone who builds one who does have equipment to measure the gain. I have gotten a good signal with a laptop (using its built-in antenna) at a distance of 700 feet (over 200 meters) from the access point.

comments.text: This is awesome, I can vouch for the practicality of this as a Wireless ISP operator - putting one of these on an antenna seems to double or more the reach of an antenna in the direction you point it at, we used the 3D printed version but also have a laser cutter for hard plastics which is a lot more practical for outdoor related equipment. Having calculated the sizing for thicker gauge quire is a bonus too. Great job, cheers!

title: GTA V - Epsilon Program Emblem
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Kifflom!

The Epsilon Program is a fictitious religious cult in the Grand Theft Auto 3D and HD Universes. It is led by Cris Formage and his several cohorts in and out of the current paradigm. Its adherents are known as epsilonists. They believe that there are several paradigms although only the 4th, 9th, and 10th are mentioned.

This is a replica of the emblem which you can see on the gates that give access to the Epsilon Program's Headquarters in Grand Theft Auto V, and that took me only a week to reproduce with Sketchup.
The model's size is approximately 206 mm, because it was designed to be used either as a particular room or door ornament...with the proper painting, of course. I would recommend a bright gold paint for this ornament.

Kifflom, brothers-brothers!

remixed_from.title: X-Carve 33mm Laser Holder w/ Scope Mount & Safety Panels

description.text:
This set of three parts provides a mounting system for the 15W TTL enabled, focusable laser from AliExpress (https://www.aliexpress.com/item/High-Power-Diode-Laser-15W-15000mW-Focusable-Blue-Laser-Module-450-445nm-with-TTL-Driver-for/32757380573.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.03ASzf)

It includes a laser holder which is a remix of the X-Carve Laser Holder w/ Scope Mount & Safety Panels by AustinSaintAubin modified to accept the 40mm wide 15w laser. It also includes a mount plate to attach the laser controller behind the Z-axis motor and a plate for mounting the 12V 6A power supply to the X-Carve sideboard.

The power supply mount requires two M3 x 10mm cap head screws to mount the supply to the plate and two M5 x 16mm screws to mount the plate to the sideboard.

The controller mount uses the existing Z-stepper screws (they should have 3mm of available thread,) to mount to the carriage and two M3 screws to mount to the controller. I used an M3 nut on each screw between the plate and controller to act as a standoff since the controller gets hot. I also added a strip of aluminum foil tape to the top of the plate under the controller since I printed in PLA. Between the standoff and the reflective tape, I haven't had heat problems yet. Print in ABS for better heat resistance.

description.text:
This is a watchband for a Pebble watch. 22mm wide. This is mysecond attempt at making and designing myself some watchbands. For hardware parts, I took pins and buckle from my original Pebble Time Steel band.

I printed using NijaFlex TPU at 225-230 degrees. This was designed in Solidworks. I printed this with the top face down. This gives the surface a matt finish from the blue tape on my printer bed.

Once I turned the print temp down to 225 degrees I stopped having the stringy threads issue. Print speed 20mm/s. Travel 80mm/s. Good clean print. Look at turquoise watchband.

I like this watch band. It's very comfortable.

I loved simiboy's snap on gear design, but I wanted something small to fit into my hand, so I Remixed something wonderful into something just my speed.

I carry this with me all the time. I fidget with it constantly. I love it more than anything else in this entire universe. (not really)

BE CAREFUL: The fit is tight. When you snap them together use as much vertical pressure as possible to place the strain onto all three stems. I will upload a loosey goosey version soon.

UPDATE: I have added a second model (fidget_loose) with the inner part of the gear expanded. This will lessen the chance of a stem breaking while snapping it together.

The more you fidget, the smoother it works. If you have a tight fit, or the movement is not smooth, you can squeeze some toothpaste into the center, and sticky fidget for a few minutes.
After you rinse it all off with water and blow it dry, the operation will be smooth and relaxing. Be sure to make a wish while blowing it dry.

description.text:
This is a replacement Chinese Checkers Peg I did for a family game.

A version of this game that has been in the family for many years had lost several pieces. Having got tired of using other odds and ends to replace the missing pieces I created this part to match the original pegs.

The part is quite small so the surface can come out rough depending on the filament used. Light sanding with fine emery cloth or a file smooths out the surface enough to be painted and look very much like the original pegs. The bottom end fits in a drill chuck to make the operation easier if needed.

The part is Cura scaled and oriented for printing.

title: FLSUN Delta Power Supply Switch Mount and Contact Cover

description.text:
I love the FLSUN Delta printer. Purchased it a few months ago. It's performed very well. One minor but recurring inconvenience is the power supply... No switch, and exposed electrical contacts. So, I decided to solve both problems in one swipe. Just add a mini rectangular SPST rocker switch. Be sure to properly insulate the leads because the cord provided with the power supply isn't grounded. When printing, rotate so that the front faces down for zero overhangs and best finish. Attach to the case with two 8mm M3 screws. You might need to trim some edges to get the holes to line up. I've found those super sharp chinese wire cutters do a great job cleaning up prints. Print the cover in any color you like. I dont' think the supply gets hot enough to worry about ABS or PLA, unless you've modified the cover. The power light bezel is optional. Print it in clear, and press into the square hole on the front panel. I didn't upload a picture with the bezel in place... but, it looks and fits well.

Note that the switch face is higher than the metal power supply cover because of the room required for the switch and contacts.

Printer:

FLSUN Delta

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.4 mm

Infill:

solid

author: runboyusa

description.text:
Now has suitable forms for all three sizes.
Size A - vform_r1_1.stl
Size B - VisorFormMedium_r1_0.stl
Size C - VisorFormSmall_r1_0.stl
These are vac forms to produce a PETG visor ( from 60 thou sheet ) for the Halo 4 Helmet Size A, B, C - see sources.
You need 2 of these on the 11 by 17 vacuum bed, to ensure the webbing only occurs between the back faces as per the photos.
This method turned it from a struggle to manipulate the plastic with bad webbing occurring to a single operation of directly pulling the plastic down on the vacuum and allowing it to form as it sees fit.
There is now no webbing on the critical faces.
Note the of the two forms
1: Painted, 2 coats primer / filler, two coats metallic color ( because I could ) 2 coats clear enamel from duplicolor rattle cans.
2: Plain straight off the printer at standard 0.2 mm resolution, no finishing.
Both formed very well, but the layers were just visible on the unpainted instance, whereas the painted version was very clear with no artefacts, so recommend painting forms by default.
The first time I pulled on the painted instance some of the clear coat adhered to the visor, I now use pledge spray on the form and the bed seal to help release the mold.
Both forms extracted from the sheet with a little compressed air into the edge and no marring or loss of clear coat.
Built a hot box and vac bed suitable for the form size, approx 11 x 17 inches.
Note the 1.1 form is mostly hollow, has grab handles for extraction and screw points to insert screws that will sit in the vac form bed holes to keep everything stable when in use, on a 1 inch matrix.
rendered image shows areas to be preserved in red and gold, so you have the visor, a surround that mates to the inside of the helmet, and the magnet mount points.
Place magnets on rear of visor to attach to helmet against magnets embedded in helmet visor edge.
Form includes overlapping edges so visor sits well and sealed right around.

"OK,", says my friend, "I've been busting my skull with this broken plane handle for years; you can't get them for love nor money, can you make that?"

title: Thomas the Train Trackmaster Lego Car

description.text:
This is a train car for the Thomas the Train Trackmaster train set. This car has a flat "Lego" top for building on. This is my first Thingiverse submission, designed after hearing my children argue over who gets to play with which train car. Now they can build their own!

This object was created with Sketchup Make. The SKP file is included, feel free to modify as you like.

See the Post-Printing notes for more information. I'm not 100% satisfied with how you need to clip the top to the bottom with the "connector" piece in this model. I'm open to suggestions on how to improve that!

Note: I borrowed the Lego components from the Lego Brick Thingiverse design by Ben Peters (bengineering): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:377523

Printer:

Da Vinci Jr. 1.0w

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I printed this on my XYZPrinting Da Vinci Jr. 1.0w on the "Excellent" quality setting with a Raft. I think that the Raft was necessary on my printer due to the small hook pieces.

Support Removal Post Printing Support Removal and Assembly

After printing you will need to remove the 5 supports from the "bottom" wheeled part if you did not print the no_supports object. I was able to just cut these with a knife. I also needed to sand down the top piece where the connector clip goes to get a better fit.

The wheels should start turning with little effort, but needed some working to get them loose enough to roll on their own.

Assembly:

1) Place the "hook" parts in the appropriate opening on the "bottom" piece. The front hook's mouth should face down.

2) Place the "top" part on top of the "bottom" and then use the "connector" clip to hold the two together. My PLA filament was flexible enough to allow this, hopefully this works for you as well.

author: drunnells

print_settings.Notes:: Print the first layer slow at about 15 - 20 mm/sec to get the best resolution on the indented letters.  When printing in PLA I start out with the bed at 60C and at 0.5mm of height I drop it to 45C.  This keeps the part from warping during the print.  For part removal I wait till the part is completely cool and use a chisel (bevel side down) to gently pry up around the edges.  The part pops off the bed after application in several places.

remixed_from.author: JP1
remixed_from.title: 4E3D Main Board Cover - RB2, RB3, RB & RBB upgrades

title: 4E3D Main Board Cover with I2C - RB3 and RBB3

description.text:
This is a modified version of the 4E3D main board cover to accommodate the I2C expansion card for use with the Skip-Sense detection and correction system.

It can be used on any printer using the new board and works in conjunction with the back-plate mounting and upgrade systems already published.

The new board cover provides a location to secure the I2C expansion card to the front of the board. Two fiber washers (same as the ones used as the heated bed bolt washers) under the PCB at the location of each both are required to provide the correct standoff from the cover and keep everything parallel.

The STL file is Cura scaled and oriented for printing.

Notes:

Print the first layer slow at about 15 - 20 mm/sec to get the best resolution on the indented letters. When printing in PLA I start out with the bed at 60C and at 0.5mm of height I drop it to 45C. This keeps the part from warping during the print. For part removal I wait till the part is completely cool and use a chisel (bevel side down) to gently pry up around the edges. The part pops off the bed after application in several places.
